greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of ways that prime(n) can be represented as a^2+b^2+c^2 with c >= b >= a > 0.
link: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..10000
mathematica: lim=25; pLst=Table[0, {PrimePi[lim^2]}]; Do[n=a^2+b^2+c^2; If[n<lim^2 && PrimeQ[n], pLst[[PrimePi[n]]]++ ], {a, lim}, {b, a, Sqrt[lim^2-a^2]}, {c, b, Sqrt[lim^2-a^2-b^2]}; pLst
xref: Cf. A085317 (primes that are the sum of three positive squares), A094712 (primes that are not the sum of three positive squares), A094714 (least prime having exactly n representations as the sum of three positive squares).
results.author: _T. D. Noe_, May 21 2004
